item.title: She Struggled With Addiction, Then Tried a Weight Loss Drug
item.description: Is a powerful addiction treatment already invented?

item.title: The Real Trump Factor in the Gaza Deal
item.description: The secret of Donald Trump’s success with the Israeli prime minister was offering carrots on domestic politics — not sticks on foreign policy.

item.title: World Liberty Financial Is a Powerful Vehicle for Those Seeking Influence
item.description: Trump’s crypto windfall represents a mixing of personal and government interests at an unprecedented scale.

item.title: Mamdani ‘Might Be Eaten Alive’: 3 Opinion Writers on Who Won the Mayoral Debate
item.description: Who lost the debate may be clearer than who won.

item.title: Chatbots Are a Waste of A.I.’s Real Potential
item.description: Generative A.I. can do many things human beings can do. But that misses the point about how A.I. can truly benefit us.

item.title: Can the Israel-Hamas Deal Hold?
item.description: The veteran Middle East negotiators Hussein Agha and Robert Malley discuss the promises and pitfalls of Trump’s peace deal.

item.title: The Israel-Gaza War Always Had an Unacknowledged Third Front
item.description: Thousands of hostages are still awaiting freedom.

item.title: NATO Must Act to Stop Russia’s Dangerous New Campaign
item.description: The only way to contain Putin is with a resolute show of strength.

item.title: How Baby Boomers Blew Up the American Dream
item.description: The postwar generation had a good run. Now we’re all paying for it.

item.title: I Have Parkinson’s: A Range of Voices
item.description: Readers, many with Parkinson’s, respond to an article about Sue Goldie, who has the disease. Also: Tears over Trump’s America; losing to China; learning through play.

item.title: Francesca Albanese Documents the Worst Crime Humanity Can Inflict. She’s an Optimist.
item.description: Francesca Albanese’s provocative allegations have made her a villain to some and a hero to others.

item.title: Something Is Stirring in Christian America, and It’s Making Me Nervous
item.description: Don’t mistake a revolution for a revival.

item.title: The Autism Spectrum Is Too Broad
item.description: I fear that the my daughter’s experience is too often sidelined in favor of a more palatable version.

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Looking Beyond the Trump Era
item.description: What do we expect from the Supreme Court and what can it actually do? On “Interesting Times,” Justice Amy Coney Barrett and Ross Douthat discuss how the court makes decisions, with an eye toward the future, rather than focusing on the moment we live in right now.

item.title: Why Was Roe v. Wade Overturned?
item.description: Abortion isn’t a right protected by the Constitution nor is it deeply rooted in the country’s history. Justice Amy Coney Barrett describes how the Supreme Court’s majority came to that conclusion on this week’s episode of “Interesting Times.” She tells Ross Douthat the tools she uses to interpret the law.

item.title: How Boomers Blew Up the American Dream
item.description: Baby boomers had a good run. Now we’re all paying for it.

item.title: The ‘Sewer Socialism’ of Zohran Mamdani
item.description: The way to advance his worldview, he argues, is to show that it works.

item.title: Trump’s Troubling ‘Compact’ for Universities
item.description: Responses to an essay about President Trump’s “Compact for Academic Excellence in Higher Education.” Also: Bikes in the park; a vigil against political violence.

item.title: Circumcision Is Controversial. Of Course Kennedy Links It to Autism.
item.description: Circumcision is the latest example of Kennedy seizing on a hot-button issue that already has entrenched and aggressive internet partisans.

item.title: In the Middle East, It’s Right Vs. Right
item.description: Who would have imagined I’d ever praise something Trump did in the world of foreign policy?

item.title: The Shadow of Jim Crow Looms Over the Supreme Court
item.description: Will Black voters continue to have an opportunity to elect representatives of their choice, or will decades of hard-won progress disappear?

item.title: A Lesson From the German Resistance That Applies Today
item.description: The best safeguard against tyranny is a legion of people who believe in an authority higher than any political program.

item.title: When I Look at Zohran Mamdani, Here’s What I See
item.description: What does it mean to be a “good” Muslim in America?

item.title: Amy Coney Barrett Is Looking Beyond the Trump Era
item.description: The Supreme Court justice isn’t making decisions based on public opinion.

item.title: When Vanity Is Your Superpower
item.description: Ten years into the Trump era, Democrats still don’t seem to know how to respond.

item.title: ‘What Can Burn Will Burn’
item.description: It seemed that last year’s wildfire in Los Angeles had been extinguished safely after two days. But it had just gone underground.

item.title: Pope Leo’s ‘Dilexi Te’ Needs to Be More Specific
item.description: A pious vision of political economy should get more concrete.

item.title: Will A.I. Actually Want to Kill Humanity?
item.description: The researcher Eliezer Yudkowsky says that what A.I. wants most is not for humanity to live “happily ever after.” “What the entity, the organism, the A.I. ends up wanting has been and will be weird and twisty.” Yudkowsky sits down with the Times Opinion columnist Ezra Klein to discuss.

item.title: You Made It to Harvard. But You Skip Class?
item.description: Readers respond to a Page A1 article about the lack of class attendance at Harvard. Also: Canceling a report on threats; America today.

item.title: The A.I. Bubble Looks Real
item.description: Like the dot-com bust and the housing crisis, an implosion of the A.I. boom would hurt.

item.title: How Afraid of the A.I. Apocalypse Should We Be?
item.description: The researcher Eliezer Yudkowsky argues that we should be very afraid of artificial intelligence’s existential risks.

item.title: What Trump’s Peace Deal Really Means for Gaza
item.description: The war might have ended, one lawyer argues, but the occupation remains.

item.title: Trump Alone Can’t Save Argentina
item.description: An American bailout can carry the country only so far.

item.title: The New Julia Roberts Movie Seethes With Anti-Woke Resentment
item.description: The reactionary centrism of “After the Hunt.”

item.title: Pete Buttigieg on Rebuilding America After Trump
item.description: The former transportation secretary argues Americans need a new sense of belonging.

item.title: Mr. Trump, on the Middle East, Please Move Fast and Break Things
item.description: Message to Trump: As hard as Stage 1 was for Gaza peace, you have not even seen hard yet.

item.title: Why Israel Won the War
item.description: Israelis went to war to defeat an existential threat — and an existential lie.

item.title: The Rise of the Smartphone and the Fall of Western Democracy
item.description: We are paying a tremendous political and psychological cost for access to social media.

item.title: A New Chapter for Israel and Gaza
item.description: Readers respond to news and opinion articles about “this historic moment” in the Middle East. Also: Dangerous obstacles to Covid vaccines.

item.title: It’s Not Normal to Raise Children Like This
item.description: We long for community. Why do so few of us try to build it?

item.title: Why So Many Gen Z-ers Are Drawn to Conservative Christianity
item.description: And what that might mean for the future of American politics.

item.title: How to Save the Craft Beer Industry
item.description: Drinking is down, but there are a few simple fixes that can get people hoisting their cans again.

item.title: Today’s Immigration Raids Echo Across a Century
item.description: Lessons from previous anti-immigrant sweeps don’t look good for the Trump administration.

item.title: Law Schools Are Using Security Concerns to Silence Speech
item.description: A principle is hollow if it’s not defended under pressure.

item.title: Is There a Place for Religion in Politics?
item.description: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks. Also: The marring of the White House; a sharp right turn to populism.

item.title: The Appalling Campaign to Erase Jan. 6 Never Ends
item.description: Trump and his Republican minions won’t rest until the truth of that day is buried.
